snippet: The defection of Syria’s prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, planned furtively for weeks, spurred jubilation in the opposition but seemed unlikely to end the war.
abstract: Defection of Syria's Prime Min Riyad Farid Hijab, planned furtively for weeks, spurs jubilation in the opposition but seems unlikely to end the conflict; is a sign that the government of Pres Bashar al-Assad is weakening.

byline.original: By DAMIEN CAVE and DALAL MAWAD
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Hwaida Saad from Beirut; Ranya Kadri from Amman, Jordan; Kareem Fahim from Cairo; an employee of The New York Times from Aleppo, Syria; Steven Lee Myers from Washington; Alan Cowell from London; and J. David Goodman from New York.

lead_paragraph: The defection of Syria’s prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, planned furtively for weeks, spurred jubilation in the opposition but seemed unlikely to end the war.

headline.seo: Defection in the Dark by the Prime Minister Jolts Syrians
headline.main: Prime Minister’s Defection in the Dark Jolts Syrians
headline.print_headline: A Defection In the Dark Jolts Syrians

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
